bestBHT.bht: The purpose of our redemption is to serve the Lord God of Israel in holiness and righteousness before Him, without fear. This deliverance from our enemies empowers us to wholeheartedly dedicate ourselves to the Author of our salvation. As adopted children of God, we are called to obey, honor, and worship Him. Serving the Lord without slavish fear, we joyfully love and serve Him in every thought, word, and work. Our redemption by Christ lays a great obligation on us to glorify Him through our service.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The purpose of all redemption—'that we should serve Him'—that is, 'the Lord God of Israel'."
The nature of this service—'in holiness and righteousness before Him'—or, as in His presence.
Its fearlessness—'might serve Him without fear'.
Albert Barnes: Might serve him - Might obey, honor, and worship him.
Without fear - Fear of death, of spiritual enemies, or of external foes.
Marvin Vincent: Serve [λατρευειν] . Originally to serve for hire, from latron, hire. Plato uses it of the service of God.
John Calvin: That being delivered out of the hand of our enemies His purpose was, that, being redeemed, they might dedicate and consecrate themselves entirely to the Author of their salvation.
We are admitted by adoption into the family of God, that we, on our part, may yield obedience as children to a father.

Those who are ill at ease, who have an inward struggle, whether God is favorable or hostile to them, whether he accepts or rejects their services,—in a word, who fluctuate in uncertainty between hope and fear, will sometimes labor anxiously in the worship of God, but never will sincerely or honestly obey him.
Philip Schaff: To grant unto us. This gives the purpose both of the oath and the approaching fulfilment of it.
Being delivered from the hand of our enemies, such as Antiochus Epiphanes and the Romans, who had interfered with the Jews in their worship.
Without fear, the emphatic phrase of the sentence. It means: without fear of enemies; the fear of God, which is the Old Testament token of piety, is implied in the next verse.
Archibald T. Robertson: Delivered (ρυσθεντας). The accusative case appears, where the dative could have been used to agree with ημιν, because of the infinitive λατρευειν (verse Luke 1:74).
But Plato uses the word of service for God so that the bad sense does not always exist.
John Gill: One principal end of deliverance from spiritual enemies by Christ, is the service of God.
Nothing lays a greater obligation on men to serve the Lord, and glorify him, than redemption by Christ.
Greater is he that serves from love, than he that serves from fear.
John Wesley: To serve him without fear — Without any slavish fear.
Here is the substance of the great promise.
That we shall be always holy, always happy: that being delivered from Satan and sin, from every uneasy and unholy temper, we shall joyfully love and serve God, in every thought, word, and work.

bhtAttempts.bht: The purpose of our redemption is to serve the Lord God of Israel, in holiness and righteousness before Him, without fear. This service is not driven by a self-serving motive, but rather a sincere dedication and consecration of ourselves to the Author of our salvation. Through redemption, we are adopted into the family of God, and as His children, we are called to obey, honor, and worship Him. This deliverance from our enemies not only frees us from their oppression but also empowers us to wholeheartedly serve the Lord without any slavish fear, always loving and joyfully dedicating ourselves to Him in every aspect of our lives.

The purpose of our redemption is to serve the Lord God of Israel, in holiness and righteousness before Him, without fear. This service is not driven by a self-serving motive, but rather a sincere dedication and consecration of ourselves to the Author of our salvation. Through redemption, we are adopted into the family of God, and as His children, we are called to obey, honor, and worship Him. This deliverance from our enemies not only frees us from their oppression but also empowers us to serve the Lord without any slavish fear, always loving and joyfully dedicating ourselves to Him in every aspect of our lives.

The purpose of our redemption is to serve the Lord God of Israel in holiness and righteousness before Him, without fear. This deliverance from our enemies empowers us to wholeheartedly dedicate ourselves to the Author of our salvation. As adopted children of God, we are called to obey, honor, and worship Him. Serving the Lord without slavish fear, we joyfully love and serve Him in every thought, word, and work. Our redemption by Christ lays a great obligation on us to glorify Him through our service.

The purpose of our redemption is to serve the Lord God of Israel in holiness and righteousness before Him, without fear. When we are delivered from our enemies, we are able to dedicate ourselves entirely to the Author of our salvation. As adopted children of God, we are to obey, honor, and worship Him. Serving the Lord without slavish fear, we joyfully love and serve Him in every thought, word, and work, always living in holiness and happiness.

The purpose of our redemption is to serve the Lord God of Israel in holiness and righteousness before Him, in a way that is fearless and without the burden of earthly concerns. Through this deliverance, we are invited into the family of God, adopting the role of His obedient and worshipful children. By being freed from spiritual enemies, our worship can be earnest and sincere, allowing us to dedicate ourselves wholly to God and glorify Him through our service.
